div1.p: Today March 11th 1840, the commercial commission of Gorée, reunited itself, on the convocation of its President, to listen to the lecture of a ministerial dispatch from December 2nd 1839, relative to the question of establishing the respective equality of the taxes affecting the flag, in regard to the french and american vessels weighing the navigation between the United States and Gorée and reciprocally.
were present.
Mr. M. Guibert, Chief of the admif service, President. ferroliet, negociator huchard} Merchant f. Dupuy.} Merchant Jh Ware} inhabitant Jn Dupuy} inhabitant

The Commission ignores what are the rights that one pays to the United States on the merchandise that is admitted there, but it would be necessary that they are made weak so that they make less than those perceived in Gorée on the products of the Union that are admitted in the rights and are found ported opposite
in Gorée on the products of the Union that are submitted and of which the rights are found ported opposite.
It is well recognized that the rights perceived in Gorée are excessively weak, comparatively to those perceived in France.

Martinique and Guadeloupe are expediting vessels to the United States; these vessels when they are on ballast only pay a right of 0.50, whereas those expedited from St Louis seen from Gorée even though not being equal. that in ballast, are submitted to a right of tonnage of one Dollar, and yet when the american vessels are admitted to introduce laws to the colonies of the West, Cabaes and provisions they pay on the products 61% which is much more risen than the rights perceived in Gorée on identical articles, and on the meal a right that is 20. f. at least per barrel.

As for that which is said relatively on the exclusion of american vessels in St Louis, it is not for the su Country se of the Union only that this non admission has place, it extends to all of the flags and yet the other nations do not claim this in order to make us pay a higher rate for the right of tonnage of the vessels that are expedited from Senegal, we can cite the support of that which we advance, that french vessels expedited form the port of St Louis, Senegal,

only paying in England that which the french vessels pay leaving from completely different ; we that the products from the coast of Africa only paying in England the same right to which are imposed the .

In Gambia, to Rathard, we only pay the same tonnage and anchorage as the nationnaux, we pay equally the same right as the english who come directely from England, and yet the English are not admitted in St Louis.
The Commission decides in the majority of four voices on its:

Then the americans only pay on our island the weak right of per barrel, and still are we in the obligation of taking the in to place them aboard their boats without taking any retribution; that their nation by reciprocity does perceive more when our vessels are going to visit the ports of America.
Or, that one makes it paid to the americans one Dollar like they impose on us, or 5. 25; it would result in a large good for french commerce The Americans would not come in as big of a number

the Americans would not come in as big of a number and the proprietors of french vessels being certain not to have concurrence, or to have one nearly as bad, would expedite a big number of vessels which would be advantageous for our commerce that do not often find freight in Senegal for France would do operations linked in porting oxen to the Antilles and raising again for one of the ports of the Union to return to Gorée or to St Louis.
In either of these two cases, it would result in a large benefit for the fise and in the last a an even bigger good for french navigation and commerce.

There is another observation that must especially be taken into consideration, which is that the americans only want the most recent receipt in payment of their marches that the individuals that are leaving the Colony to never return.

It should be remarked in addition, that the americans pay on the skins, rubbers, bois de cail-cedra at least on all of the products that they are authorized to export, the same right that that to which the french are subjugated
subjugated at the exit, even when these products are directed to the french ports.
The goal of the reunion being filled, the session is finished and the present official report signed the jous but that dessus

The Chief of administrative Service President of the Committee of Commerce.
M.
